Hello, BASIC!

In this first installment of "Code Like It's 198x," we'll take a look at the BASIC programming language and how its concepts still influence modern development.

A Brief History

BASIC (Beginner's All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code) was created in 1964 at Dartmouth College by John G. Kemeny and Thomas E. Kurtz. It was designed to be an easy-to-learn language for students who weren't necessarily computer science majors.

Sample Code

Here's a classic "Hello, World!" program in BASIC:

basic 10 PRINT "HELLO, WORLD!" 20 GOTO 10

Modern Equivalents

While BASIC itself isn't widely used today, many of its concepts live on in modern languages. For example:

javascript // Modern JavaScript equivalent while (true) { console.log("Hello, World!"); }

Key Concepts

  • Line numbers (10, 20, etc.)
  • GOTO statements
  • Simple I/O operations
  • Basic control structures

Why It Matters Today

BASIC's influence can be seen in modern programming education. Its emphasis on simplicity and immediate feedback helped shape how we teach programming today.
